Articles.Content:
A kerbal is 64% the size of a human, so it's logical that all human rocket are scaled down to fit their size if they use it. Think to a midget, I think it's Volkswagen that made a Golf downscaled to fit the size of a couple of midget.

Kerbals are of different proportions than humans, so there's no point making KSP rockets exactly scaled with Kerbals, because often, their heads wouldn't fit, as with Soyuz. So you either make the interior bigger than the external model or forgo the 64% scaling altogether and just go for "close enough". Since the latter approach allows much higher flexibility (because it can be made compatible with "standard" part sizes), I prefer it.

.

I find KOSMOS to be way too large, never mind the weird blue colour all the parts have...

Kerbals are of different proportions than humans, so there's no point making KSP rockets exactly scaled with Kerbals, because often, their heads wouldn't fit, as with Soyuz. So you either make the interior bigger than the external model or forgo the 64% scaling altogether and just go for "close enough". Since the latter approach allows much higher flexibility (because it can be made compatible with "standard" part sizes), I prefer it.

Yeah, midget size are proportionally different too The point is, if you scale the rockets exactly as they're IRL, it'll be almost 2 times too big. I understand what you're saying with the interior, but I prefer have an interior that is almost proportioned and the whole rocket nicely proportioned than a rocket way too big for our tiny kerbals. And do you really think that if you were 64% your size and your head was 3/4 of your body you'd still want to drive a car that's as big as a normal human sized one ?

It's a game about little green men, not to mention an alpha. I'm not advocating scaling them as they're IRL, I'm advocating scaling them to what works best. Is that so difficult to understand? 64% gives a weird size that can't be used with anything but itself, not to mention it's impossible to downscale some parts (Soyuz) to that size, because the crew wouldn't fit. I'm only asking for exteriors to be proportional with each other, and to fit nicely with standard diameters. Currently, BobCat fails at both. The former, since the Soyuz (and because of that, Progress and Kliper) aren't rescaled to 64%, and the latter because stuff that is rescaled to 64% is halfway between 2.5m and 3.75m, therefore not fitting with either.

Currently, BobCat fails at both.

Yea..i love fail projects. ))

therefore not fitting with either.

Edited April 22, 2013 by BobCat

To make Bobcat Mir and Soyuz scale together as they should (and to fit with Kosmos scale), you can edit the cfgs like this:

Mir modules: rescaleFactor = 1.25

Mir probe: rescaleFactor = 1

Mir docking ports: rescaleFactor = 0.85

Proton parts: rescaleFactor = 1.25

Soyuz: rescaleFactor = 1

Soyuz Block-D: rescaleFactor = 1.8 (also set the LiquidFuel and Oxidizer to 720 and 880)

Note: cBBp's parts are not perfect either. I've had to rescale the KVTK tanks to 2.1 and the Dragon to 1, and all the Kosmos parts are too heavy. But that's the fun of having modifiable cfg files. You can set everything the way you really want it.
That full size kerbal overlay is rather... unsettling.

After rescale i do not guarantee the correct operation of all the parts. With the increasing size of the parts is weakening the power of the node points and surface connections. You may be faced with very strong wooble.

Well, it's the fact that the interiors stop working properly because their size does not change. )))

Also about CBBP parts.

If you change mass you have wooble too. )))

In KSP world the smaller part, the better for physics. ))
